{'uri': '8230373147', 'lang': 'eng', 'isDuplicate': False, 'date': '2024-07-17', 'time': '16:44:13', 'dateTime': '2024-07-17T16:44:13Z', 'dateTimePub': '2024-07-17T16:43:41Z', 'dataType': 'news', 'sim': 0.4313725531101227, 'url': 'https://www.splinter.com/copa-america-was-already-embarrassing-before-the-disastrous-final-took-it-to-the-next-level', 'title': 'Copa America Was Already Embarrassing Before the Disastrous Final Took It to the Next Level', 'body': 'Sunday\'s Copa America final in Miami was disastrous on several fronts. The tournament was supposed to function as the dress rehearsal for the United States hosting the World Cup in two years, but it raised more questions than answers about soccer\'s biggest spectacle.\n\nMany of the stadiums used for this tournament, also to be used for the \'26 World Cup, are massive football stadiums with turf fields. To conform with international soccer\'s requirements for grass fields, the solution is often to lay grass over the turf and hope it holds up.\n\nAT&T Stadium in Arlington, Texas, which looked as if it might be awarded a World Cup final but settled for a semifinal and eight other matches instead, got positive reports from American players on how its grass-over-turf performed. MetLife Stadium in New Jersey, which was awarded the World Cup final, and Mercedes-Benz Stadium in Atlanta, where Argentina opened its title run, drew more negative reviews for their playing surfaces.\n\nArgentine goalkeeper Emi Martinez -- you know, the one who won the \'22 World Cup\'s Golden Glove award and then did the most juvenile thing you could possibly do with it in front of his stern Qatari hosts -- declared per ESPN, "The state of the pitch was a disaster." His manager, Lionel Scaloni, added, "The field is not apt for these players." Canada\'s Kamal Miller, on the losing end of that 2-0 match, chimed in as well, noting that "It felt like walking on a stage, as if it was hollow."\n\nMetLife had field issues compounding its inherent problem being a concrete monstrosity eight harrowing miles away from midtown Manhattan. After her experience getting to and from the venue, TV personality Julie Stewart-Binks tweeted, "I have no idea how Met Life is going to host the World Cup Final."\n\nUruguay head coach Marcelo Bielsa let loose in a press conference ahead of its third-place match -- AKA the match no one wants to play, yet major international tournaments still insist on staging. He criticized playing surfaces, the training grounds, the U.S.\'s role in bringing charges against FIFA executives in 2015 (a long story), and perhaps more alarmingly, the chaos that ensued following Uruguay\'s semifinal loss to Colombia, when some of Bielsa\'s players went into the stands at Charlotte\'s Bank of America Stadium to fight Colombian fans under the premise of protecting their families.\n\nCritics should not pin this entirely on U.S. organizers, though. CONMEBOL, the federation governing 10 of South America\'s 12 sovereign nations, ran the tournament, held in the U.S. for the second time in a decade. (The centennial edition of the irregularly-staged event, in 2016, saw Chile vanquish Argentina in penalties in the final, which happened to be at MetLife.)\n\nBielsa, by the way, said CONMEBOL is run by a "plague of liars."\n\nThis year\'s final in Miami\'s Hard Rock Stadium was described by the Miami Herald as "marred by thousands of unruly fans -- many without tickets -- who stormed the gates, scaled walls, jumped turnstiles and even slithered through vents to get a glimpse of the spectacle."\n\nMiami-Dade Police and Fire Rescue demanded the stadium\'s gates be opened hours before kickoff in a Sophie\'s Choice of either letting in thousands, many of whom did not have tickets, or risking injuries or even deaths in a sweltering crush.\n\nWhat it led to, though, was thousands of fans holding actual tickets left outside while gatecrashers who avoided haphazardly enforced ticket checks got to enjoy the match once it started -- well over an hour after it was scheduled to begin. They also got to witness an extended Shakira halftime show that had aspirational Super Bowl vibes and helped drag the match past midnight for East Coast viewers.\n\nOne NBC Miami story followed a forlorn fan who got tickets for himself and his pregnant wife for nearly $3700, but didn\'t want to risk being crushed in the crowds. They attempted to get in through a safer gate, and ultimately weren\'t allowed in. He\'s now trying to get a refund, awaiting word on how Ticketmaster and CONMEBOL will align on this and other refund requests from similarly-disgruntled fans.\n\nCONMEBOL took to X (formerly Twitter) to blame fans and then the Hard Rock Stadium staff for the debacle despite, as Pro Soccer Wire pointed out in its coverage, declaring in its tournament guidelines that it had "full authority" over the match.\n\nCONMEBOL execs even had their violent moment in the sun: 71-year-old Colombian Football Federation president and a CONMEBOL vice president, Ramon Jesurun, was arrested for grabbing a stadium security guard by the throat, pushing him to the ground and punching him.\n\nSoccer journalist Favian Renkel tweeted, after a day of covering the mayhem, "It\'s embarrassing for an organization to be so unprepared for such a major tournament in the United States. CONMEBOL did a horrible job planning or asking for help on this, making the United States look extremely bad. There has always been a belief that the U.S. could step in if any other country was unable to host. Today\'s events suggest that belief was misplaced."\n\nThose are damning words, but consider all the video footage of the mayhem that Renkel and others pored over. That included fans hoisting aloft a half-full bottle of tequila they somehow got past security, others destroying an escalator or scaling a stadium wall to get past security, and a fan\'s shih tzu getting loose from its carrier and roaming as other fans charged past a fallen gate. Then there was the most grotesque image from the actual match: Lionel Messi\'s ankle, swollen to elephantine proportions thanks to an injury that will keep him from next week\'s MLS All-Star Game and the Leagues Cup to follow.\n\nThe best thing the U.S. World Cup hosts could do is to undertake a post-mortem immediately and establish some take-home lessons from this before it happens again on a larger scale. Installing multiple security perimeters and making sure fans without tickets can\'t get anywhere near any of the stadiums would be a good start, but it goes beyond that. Ultimately, FIFA will be in charge of this tournament, and the U.S.\'s northern and southern neighbors will also be co-hosts; but embarrassment from any mishaps, though, will likely come down almost entirely on the U.S.', 'source': {'uri': 'splinter.com', 'dataType': 'news', 'title': 'Splinter'}, 'authors': [], 'image': 'https://img.pastemagazine.com/wp-content/suploads/2024/07/Copa-Final-Miami-e1721228759196.jpg', 'eventUri': 'eng-9732508', 'sentiment': 0.2, 'wgt': 458930653, 'relevance': 51}

{'uri': '2024-07-425062979', 'lang': 'eng', 'isDuplicate': True, 'date': '2024-07-17', 'time': '16:42:25', 'dateTime': '2024-07-17T16:42:25Z', 'dateTimePub': '2024-07-17T15:56:02Z', 'dataType': 'news', 'sim': 0, 'url': 'https://www.kansascity.com/sports/article290157804.html', 'title': 'FIFA investigates Argentina for racist Copa America celebration chant', 'body': 'July 17 (UPI) -- FIFA opened an investigation into Argentina after players were heard singing a racist chant while celebrating their victory over Colombia in the Copa America finale, the world soccer governing body said Wednesday.\n\n"FIFA is aware of a video circulating on social media and the incident is being looked into," FIFA said in a statement. "FIFA strongly condemns any form of discrimination by anyone including players, fans and officials."\n\nA video of the players signing the chant surfaced after the Argentines beat Colombia 1-0 on Sunday at Hard Rock Stadium in Miami Gardens, Fla.\n\nArgentina midfielder Enzo Fernandez was among the players who posted footage from a bus, featuring his teammates singing the chant that included racist and homophobic insults. The song also features a slight directed at France striker Kylian Mbappe, one of Argentine captain Lionel Messi\'s former teammates.\n\nThe chant, which some Argentina fans sang at the 2022 World Cup final during a win over France, also cites French players with African ancestors and others from immigrant families.\n\n"They play for France, but their parents are from Angola," part of the chant says. "Their mother is from Cameroon while their father is from Nigeria. But their passport says French."\n\nThe French Football Federation announced Tuesday that president Philippe Diallo made direct appeals to Argentina Football Association president Claudio Fabian Tapia and FIFA and filed a "legal complaint for racially offensive and discriminatory remarks."\n\nFernandez issued an apology Tuesday on Instagram, while admitting that the "song includes highly offensive language" and there was "absolutely no excuse" for the words.\n\n"I stand against discrimination in all forms and apologize for getting caught up in the euphoria of our Copa America celebrations," Fernandez wrote on his Instagram story.\n\n"That video, that moment, those words, do not reflect my beliefs or my character. I am truly sorry."\n\nFernandez\'s club team, Chelsea, also issued a statement, calling all forms of "discriminatory behavior completely unacceptable."\n\n"We acknowledge and appreciate our players\' public apology and will use this as an opportunity to educate," the Premier League club said. "The club has instigated an internal disciplinary procedure."\n\nDefender Wesley Fofana, one of Fernandez\'s Black Chelsea teammates, reposted the video Tuesday on X, while writing: "Football in 2024: uninhibited racism." Fofana was born in France. His mother is French, while his father is from West Africa.\n\nNeither the Argentina Football Association nor Messi have made public comments about the incident. Representatives for both parties did not immediately respond when asked for statements on the incident or investigation.\n\nConcacaf and CONMEBOL, the South American organizations that organize Copa America, also did not immediately respond when asked for comment.\n\nChelsea will host Wrexham in a friendly at 10:30 p.m. EDT July 24 at Levi\'s Stadium in Santa Clara, Calif.', 'source': {'uri': 'kansascity.com', 'dataType': 'news', 'title': 'The Kansas City Star'}, 'authors': [{'uri': 'alex_butler@kansascity.com', 'name': 'Alex Butler', 'type': 'author', 'isAgency': False}], 'image': 'https://www.mcclatchy-wires.com/incoming/1tkrf2/picture290157759/alternates/LANDSCAPE_1140/158ff095-5df1-4500-830d-60a23216228c', 'eventUri': None, 'sentiment': -0.1686274509803921, 'wgt': 458930545, 'relevance': 100}

{'uri': '8230368567', 'lang': 'eng', 'isDuplicate': False, 'date': '2024-07-17', 'time': '16:40:27', 'dateTime': '2024-07-17T16:40:27Z', 'dateTimePub': '2024-07-17T16:39:54Z', 'dataType': 'news', 'sim': 0.4941176474094391, 'url': 'https://talksport.com/football/1971250/jude-bellingham-fc-25-cover-curse/', 'title': "Bellingham hoping to avoid 'curse' after being confirmed as EA FC 25 cover star", 'body': 'Jude Bellingham\'s stunning first season at Real Madrid has seen him replace Erling Haaland on the front cover of EA Sports FC 25.\n\nBut he will be hoping to avoid the dreaded \'curse\' that a number of stars have encountered after being confirmed as the face of the franchise.\n\nThe 22-year-old scooped both the LaLiga title and Champions League in his first campaign in Spain, where he chipped in with 23 games in all competitions.\n\nAnd he also helped guide England to the Euro 2024 final where he scored twice in Germany, but failed to get his hands on his trophy with Spain emerging as 2-1 winners.\n\nBellingham\'s dazzling displays have now seen him become the new face of EA Sports\' hit video game - formerly known as FIFA - which will be released on September 27.\n\nExpressing his delight at the honour, Bellingham, the first Englishman to appear since FIFA 16, said: "I played this game with my brother all the time growing up.\n\n"I\'ve always thought about how incredible it would be to one day be featured on the cover.\n\n"There have been so many iconic players on the cover over the years, and I am delighted to be the most recent English player to be bestowed with this honour since 2011."\n\nDavid Platt was the first Englishman to appear on the cover (FIFA International Soccer 1993), followed by David Beckham in 1997 (FIFA: Road to World Cup 98).\n\nSol Campbell and Paul Scholes appeared on FIFA 2000 and FIFA 2001 respectively, with Wayne Rooney then featuring on every cover from FIFA 06-12, where he was joined by Theo Walcott and Frank Lampard in FIFA 10 and then Jack Wilshere for FIFA 12 with Jordan Henderson then on the front of FIFA 16.\n\nBut many of those Three Lions stars - and foreign players - have been blighted by bad luck and off-the-pitch issues after being named on the cover.\n\nHere talkSPORT.com takes a look at those that have been struck down by the \'curse\'.\n\n\'Golden Balls\' could do no wrong in 1997 after helping Manchester United retain the Premier League title, where he banged in 12 goals in all competitions.\n\nBut by the summer of 1998, he was public enemy No.1 in England following his red card in England\'s World Cup quarter-final exit at the hands of Argentina in France.\n\nThe Red Devils legend was shown a straight red card for a kick out at now-Atletico Madrid boss Diego Simeone.\n\nBeckham\'s petulance occurred just after the break, resulting in England playing the rest of the game - and extra-time - with ten men before losing on penalties.\n\nIt took Beckham three years to get back in fans\' good book after his late free-kick in the World Cup qualifier against Greece sent England to the World Cup, where he fully redeemed himself by scoring the winner against Argentina in the 2002 tournament.\n\nThe Arsenal icon went into the 1998/99 season on the back of scooping the Premier League and FA Cup - resulting in him being crowned as the PFA Player of the Year.\n\nAnd while he scored 16 goals the following campaign, one moment in the FA Cup semi-final loss to Manchester United affected him for the rest of his career.\n\nIn what was effectively the last kick of normal time with the scores level at 1-1, Bergkamp had the chance to send the Gunners to another final, but had his penalty was saved by Peter Schmeichel.\n\nRyan Giggs would then go on to score an iconic solo goal where he slalomed through the Arsenal backline as United won 2-1 in extra-time, before completing a historic treble.\n\nAs for Bergkamp, he never took a penalty again in his career before retiring in north London in 2006.\n\nRooney\'s first of seven straight cover appearances came in FIFA 2006, where he remains the youngest star to appear front and centre at the age of 19.\n\nDespite scoring twice in the League Cup final win over Wigan, Rooney picked up a metatarsal injury at Chelsea in April 2006 which threatened to rule him out of the World Cup.\n\nHe won his race to be involved, but never looked fully fit as he failed to score in the tournament, before he had his \'Beckham moment\' in the quarter-final defeat to Portugal.\n\nWhile Beckham kicked Simeone, Rooney stomped on Ricardo Carvalho, with Portugal going on to win on penalties, just as Argentina did eight years earlier.\n\nThe ex-Arsenal winger was marred by injuries throughout the 2009/10 campaign, restricting him to just 15 starts in all competitions.\n\nIt took him until December to play his first full match, with Walcott struggling for consistency as he battled his knocks - scoring just four goals in 30 matches.\n\nIt led Fabio Capello to leave him out his England squad for the 2010 World Cup - a decision that shocked Lionel Messi.\n\nThe Argentina legend said at the time: "I must say that at the time I thought it was a bad decision to leave Theo Walcott at home, and I think that has been proved right.\n\n"I can only speak from experience but he was one of the most dangerous players I have ever played against."\n\nBrazilian maestro Kaka finally graced the cover after his opening season at Real Madrid.\n\nBut by that point, his career was already on the decline, with a knee injury resulting in him not featuring for Los Blancos until January 2011.\n\nHe then suffered a knee setback shortly later, limiting him to just 14 LaLiga appearances.\n\nHaving burst into the Arsenal team the previous season, big things were expected of the young midfielder.\n\nAnd while he enjoyed a successful spell at the Emirates Stadium, injuries saw Wilshere retire from football aged just 30 in 2022 - with his first major setback occurring in 2011.\n\nHe suffered a stress fracture in his ankle during a pre-season game against New York Red Bulls, which saw him miss the entirety of the 2011/12 campaign.\n\nIt also saw him ruled out of featuring for England at Euro 2012 and for Team GB at the London 2012 Olympic Games.\n\nEven Messi, who by FIFA 16 was making his fourth appearance on the cover, was fell victim to the \'curse\'.\n\nHe missed in the Copa America final penalty shootout defeat to Chile, where he blazed his effort over the bar, which led to him to retire from international.\n\nMessi made a U-turn on his decision, where he has since captained the South American nation to three successive major tournament victories, including the 2022 World Cup.\n\nMeanwhile, Henderson endured a difficult 2015/16 term in his first season as Liverpool captain, with injuries restricting him to just 17 top-flight appearances.\n\nThe Reds\' poor form led to Jurgen Klopp replacing sacked Brendan Rodgers in October, with the Reds finishing in eighth spot, while also losing in both the League Cup and Europa League finals.\n\nReus was the first player in 11 years that didn\'t feature either Rooney or Messi on the cover.\n\nBut unfortunately for the Borussia Dortmund icon, he was the next to fall victim to the injury curse.\n\nHe mustered just 17 Bundesliga outings, with his absence playing a huge part in BVB finishing 18 points behind champions Bayern Munich.\n\nRonaldo made the front cover for the second year having won his fifth Champions League.\n\nThe 39-year-old had just transferred to Juventus from Real Madrid, with off-field drama resulting in him being pulled as the face during the 2018/19 season.\n\nThe decision was made following allegations of rape, with Neymar, Kevin De Bruyne and Paulo Dybala subsequently replacing him. The lawsuit against Ronaldo was later dropped by a US judge.\n\nThe Belgian winger was expected to set the world alight at Real Madrid following his initial initial ¬£88.3million move from Chelsea.\n\nBut despite Real winning the title in 2020, Hazard enjoyed a nightmare season on a personal note.\n\nMultiple injuries saw him play just 22 games in all competitions, where he found the back of the net just once.\n\nAnd he himself admitted that his opening year in Spain was the \'worst of my career\'.\n\nFor the first time in his Paris Saint-Germain career, he failed to win the Ligue 1 title, with his side being pipped by Lille to the crown.\n\nAnd he then drew a blank for France at the delayed Euro 2020, where he failed to score a single goal.\n\nMbappe then missed against Switzerland in the last 16 penalty shootout, which saw Les Bleus make a shock early exit.', 'source': {'uri': 'talksport.com', 'dataType': 'news', 'title': 'talkSPORT'}, 'authors': [{'uri': 'jake_lambourne@talksport.com', 'name': 'Jake Lambourne', 'type': 'author', 'isAgency': False}], 'image': 'https://talksport.com/wp-content/uploads/sites/5/2024/07/HB-TALKSPORT-BELLINGHAM.jpg?strip=all&quality=100&w=1500&h=1000&crop=1', 'eventUri': 'eng-9735810', 'sentiment': 0.2470588235294118, 'wgt': 458930427, 'relevance': 1}

{'uri': '2024-07-425057974', 'lang': 'eng', 'isDuplicate': True, 'date': '2024-07-17', 'time': '16:37:11', 'dateTime': '2024-07-17T16:37:11Z', 'dateTimePub': '2024-07-17T15:56:02Z', 'dataType': 'news', 'sim': 0, 'url': 'https://www.idahostatesman.com/sports/article290157804.html', 'title': 'FIFA investigates Argentina for racist Copa America celebration chant', 'body': 'July 17 (UPI) -- FIFA opened an investigation into Argentina after players were heard singing a racist chant while celebrating their victory over Colombia in the Copa America finale, the world soccer governing body said Wednesday.\n\n"FIFA is aware of a video circulating on social media and the incident is being looked into," FIFA said in a statement. "FIFA strongly condemns any form of discrimination by anyone including players, fans and officials."\n\nA video of the players signing the chant surfaced after the Argentines beat Colombia 1-0 on Sunday at Hard Rock Stadium in Miami Gardens, Fla.\n\nArgentina midfielder Enzo Fernandez was among the players who posted footage from a bus, featuring his teammates singing the chant that included racist and homophobic insults. The song also features a slight directed at France striker Kylian Mbappe, one of Argentine captain Lionel Messi\'s former teammates.\n\nThe chant, which some Argentina fans sang at the 2022 World Cup final during a win over France, also cites French players with African ancestors and others from immigrant families.\n\n"They play for France, but their parents are from Angola," part of the chant says. "Their mother is from Cameroon while their father is from Nigeria. But their passport says French."\n\nThe French Football Federation announced Tuesday that president Philippe Diallo made direct appeals to Argentina Football Association president Claudio Fabian Tapia and FIFA and filed a "legal complaint for racially offensive and discriminatory remarks."\n\nFernandez issued an apology Tuesday on Instagram, while admitting that the "song includes highly offensive language" and there was "absolutely no excuse" for the words.\n\n"I stand against discrimination in all forms and apologize for getting caught up in the euphoria of our Copa America celebrations," Fernandez wrote on his Instagram story.\n\n"That video, that moment, those words, do not reflect my beliefs or my character. I am truly sorry."\n\nFernandez\'s club team, Chelsea, also issued a statement, calling all forms of "discriminatory behavior completely unacceptable."\n\n"We acknowledge and appreciate our players\' public apology and will use this as an opportunity to educate," the Premier League club said. "The club has instigated an internal disciplinary procedure."\n\nDefender Wesley Fofana, one of Fernandez\'s Black Chelsea teammates, reposted the video Tuesday on X, while writing: "Football in 2024: uninhibited racism." Fofana was born in France. His mother is French, while his father is from West Africa.\n\nNeither the Argentina Football Association nor Messi have made public comments about the incident. Representatives for both parties did not immediately respond when asked for statements on the incident or investigation.\n\nConcacaf and CONMEBOL, the South American organizations that organize Copa America, also did not immediately respond when asked for comment.\n\nChelsea will host Wrexham in a friendly at 10:30 p.m. EDT July 24 at Levi\'s Stadium in Santa Clara, Calif.', 'source': {'uri': 'idahostatesman.com', 'dataType': 'news', 'title': 'Idaho Statesman'}, 'authors': [{'uri': 'alex_butler@idahostatesman.com', 'name': 'Alex Butler', 'type': 'author', 'isAgency': False}], 'image': 'https://www.mcclatchy-wires.com/incoming/1tkrf2/picture290157759/alternates/LANDSCAPE_1140/158ff095-5df1-4500-830d-60a23216228c', 'eventUri': None, 'sentiment': -0.1686274509803921, 'wgt': 458930231, 'relevance': 100}

{'uri': '2024-07-425054724', 'lang': 'eng', 'isDuplicate': True, 'date': '2024-07-17', 'time': '16:34:03', 'dateTime': '2024-07-17T16:34:03Z', 'dateTimePub': '2024-07-17T15:56:02Z', 'dataType': 'news', 'sim': 0, 'url': 'https://www.kansas.com/sports/article290157804.html', 'title': 'FIFA investigates Argentina for racist Copa America celebration chant', 'body': 'July 17 (UPI) -- FIFA opened an investigation into Argentina after players were heard singing a racist chant while celebrating their victory over Colombia in the Copa America finale, the world soccer governing body said Wednesday.\n\n"FIFA is aware of a video circulating on social media and the incident is being looked into," FIFA said in a statement. "FIFA strongly condemns any form of discrimination by anyone including players, fans and officials."\n\nA video of the players signing the chant surfaced after the Argentines beat Colombia 1-0 on Sunday at Hard Rock Stadium in Miami Gardens, Fla.\n\nArgentina midfielder Enzo Fernandez was among the players who posted footage from a bus, featuring his teammates singing the chant that included racist and homophobic insults. The song also features a slight directed at France striker Kylian Mbappe, one of Argentine captain Lionel Messi\'s former teammates.\n\nThe chant, which some Argentina fans sang at the 2022 World Cup final during a win over France, also cites French players with African ancestors and others from immigrant families.\n\n"They play for France, but their parents are from Angola," part of the chant says. "Their mother is from Cameroon while their father is from Nigeria. But their passport says French."\n\nThe French Football Federation announced Tuesday that president Philippe Diallo made direct appeals to Argentina Football Association president Claudio Fabian Tapia and FIFA and filed a "legal complaint for racially offensive and discriminatory remarks."\n\nFernandez issued an apology Tuesday on Instagram, while admitting that the "song includes highly offensive language" and there was "absolutely no excuse" for the words.\n\n"I stand against discrimination in all forms and apologize for getting caught up in the euphoria of our Copa America celebrations," Fernandez wrote on his Instagram story.\n\n"That video, that moment, those words, do not reflect my beliefs or my character. I am truly sorry."\n\nFernandez\'s club team, Chelsea, also issued a statement, calling all forms of "discriminatory behavior completely unacceptable."\n\n"We acknowledge and appreciate our players\' public apology and will use this as an opportunity to educate," the Premier League club said. "The club has instigated an internal disciplinary procedure."\n\nDefender Wesley Fofana, one of Fernandez\'s Black Chelsea teammates, reposted the video Tuesday on X, while writing: "Football in 2024: uninhibited racism." Fofana was born in France. His mother is French, while his father is from West Africa.\n\nNeither the Argentina Football Association nor Messi have made public comments about the incident. Representatives for both parties did not immediately respond when asked for statements on the incident or investigation.\n\nConcacaf and CONMEBOL, the South American organizations that organize Copa America, also did not immediately respond when asked for comment.\n\nChelsea will host Wrexham in a friendly at 10:30 p.m. EDT July 24 at Levi\'s Stadium in Santa Clara, Calif.', 'source': {'uri': 'kansas.com', 'dataType': 'news', 'title': 'The Wichita Eagle'}, 'authors': [{'uri': 'alex_butler@kansas.com', 'name': 'Alex Butler', 'type': 'author', 'isAgency': False}], 'image': 'https://www.mcclatchy-wires.com/incoming/1tkrf2/picture290157759/alternates/LANDSCAPE_1140/158ff095-5df1-4500-830d-60a23216228c', 'eventUri': None, 'sentiment': -0.1686274509803921, 'wgt': 458930043, 'relevance': 100}

{'uri': '8230356044', 'lang': 'eng', 'isDuplicate': False, 'date': '2024-07-17', 'time': '16:31:51', 'dateTime': '2024-07-17T16:31:51Z', 'dateTimePub': '2024-07-17T16:30:56Z', 'dataType': 'news', 'sim': 0.800000011920929, 'url': 'https://www.cbssports.com/soccer/news/argentina-copa-america-win-controversy-french-soccer-federation-files-legal-action-over-racist-chanting/', 'title': "Argentina Copa America win controversy: French Soccer Federation files legal action over 'racist' chanting - CBSSports.com", 'body': 'Chelsea\'s Enzo Fernandez at the center of controversy along with Albiceleste teammates Getty Images\n\nThe French Soccer Federation (FFF) has condemned Argentina\'s Copa America celebrations because of "racially offensive and discriminatory remarks" in their chants. Chelsea defender and France international Wesley Fofana took to social media to draw attention to the Albiceleste celebrations which his Blues teammate Enzo Fernandez broadcast to social media. The Argentina midfielder has since apologized for his actions but an FFF statement has detailed legal action as well as calling for FIFA and Argentina Football Association (AFA) action.\n\nFIFA supremo Gianni Infantino and AFA president Claudio Fabian Tapia are yet to comment publicly.\n\nWhat was in the chant?\n\nFernandez\'s footage after their Copa America final win over Colombia was noticed and reposted via social media by Fofana who branded it: "Football in 2024: uninhibited racism." Argentina\'s players are allegedly heard making references to the family lineage of France players as well as making alleged derogatory homophobic and transphobic mentions. Argentina beat France in the 2022 World Cup final on penalties which has since bred something of a rivalry after Emiliano Martinez\'s targeting of Kylian Mbappe elicited angry response in France.\n\nWhat has the FFF said?\n\n"The president of the French Football Federation, Philippe Diallo, condemns in the strongest terms the unacceptable racist and discriminatory remarks which were made against the players of the French team in the context of a song sung by players and supporters of the Argentina team after its victory in the Copa America and broadcast in a video on social media," read an official FFF statement. "Faced with the seriousness of these shocking remarks, contrary to the values of sport and human rights, the president of the FFF decided to directly challenge his Argentinian counterpart and FIFA, and to file a legal complaint for insulting remarks of a racist and discriminatory nature."\n\nAren\'t Fofana and Fernandez teammates?\n\nBoth Fofana and Fernandez play together for Chelsea and have been teammates for the past 18 months. Although the former was not involved in the 2022 World Cup final, France and Argentina playing each other has created needle which Mbappe did not help with his derogatory comments on South American soccer. Fofana is not Chelsea\'s only Frenchman with Axel Disasi and Malo Gusto also on the roster -- both have since unfollowed Fernandez on social media.\n\nHas Fernandez apologized?\n\nThe Chelsea and Argentina man has taken to social media to express his regret and to apologize for the remarks: "I want to apologize sincerely for a video posted on my Instagram channel during the national team celebrations," he wrote. "The song includes highly offensive language and there is absolutely no excuse for these words. I stand against discrimination in all forms and apologize for getting caught up in the euphoria of our Copa America celebrations. That video, that moment, those words, do not reflect my beliefs or my character. I am truly sorry."\n\nWhat comes next?\n\nFIFA and the AFA\'s stance is anticipated while Chelsea have confirmed that they will potentially take internal action: "Chelsea Football Club finds all forms of discriminatory behavior completely unacceptable," read a statement. "We are proud to be a diverse, inclusive club where people from all cultures, communities and identities feel welcome. We acknowledge and appreciate our player\'s public apology and will use this as an opportunity to educate." {'uri': '2024-07-425050332', 'lang': 'eng', 'isDuplicate': True, 'date': '2024-07-17', 'time': '16:28:39', 'dateTime': '2024-07-17T16:28:39Z', 'dateTimePub': '2024-07-17T15:56:02Z', 'dataType': 'news', 'sim': 0, 'url': 'https://www.charlotteobserver.com/sports/article290157804.html', 'title': 'FIFA investigates Argentina for racist Copa America celebration chant', 'body': 'July 17 (UPI) -- FIFA opened an investigation into Argentina after players were heard singing a racist chant while celebrating their victory over Colombia in the Copa America finale, the world soccer governing body said Wednesday.\n\n"FIFA is aware of a video circulating on social media and the incident is being looked into," FIFA said in a statement. "FIFA strongly condemns any form of discrimination by anyone including players, fans and officials."\n\nA video of the players signing the chant surfaced after the Argentines beat Colombia 1-0 on Sunday at Hard Rock Stadium in Miami Gardens, Fla.\n\nArgentina midfielder Enzo Fernandez was among the players who posted footage from a bus, featuring his teammates singing the chant that included racist and homophobic insults. The song also features a slight directed at France striker Kylian Mbappe, one of Argentine captain Lionel Messi\'s former teammates.\n\nThe chant, which some Argentina fans sang at the 2022 World Cup final during a win over France, also cites French players with African ancestors and others from immigrant families.\n\n"They play for France, but their parents are from Angola," part of the chant says. "Their mother is from Cameroon while their father is from Nigeria. But their passport says French."\n\nThe French Football Federation announced Tuesday that president Philippe Diallo made direct appeals to Argentina Football Association president Claudio Fabian Tapia and FIFA and filed a "legal complaint for racially offensive and discriminatory remarks."\n\nFernandez issued an apology Tuesday on Instagram, while admitting that the "song includes highly offensive language" and there was "absolutely no excuse" for the words.\n\n"I stand against discrimination in all forms and apologize for getting caught up in the euphoria of our Copa America celebrations," Fernandez wrote on his Instagram story.\n\n"That video, that moment, those words, do not reflect my beliefs or my character. I am truly sorry."\n\nFernandez\'s club team, Chelsea, also issued a statement, calling all forms of "discriminatory behavior completely unacceptable."\n\n"We acknowledge and appreciate our players\' public apology and will use this as an opportunity to educate," the Premier League club said. "The club has instigated an internal disciplinary procedure."\n\nDefender Wesley Fofana, one of Fernandez\'s Black Chelsea teammates, reposted the video Tuesday on X, while writing: "Football in 2024: uninhibited racism." Fofana was born in France. His mother is French, while his father is from West Africa.\n\nNeither the Argentina Football Association nor Messi have made public comments about the incident. Representatives for both parties did not immediately respond when asked for statements on the incident or investigation.\n\nConcacaf and CONMEBOL, the South American organizations that organize Copa America, also did not immediately respond when asked for comment.\n\nChelsea will host Wrexham in a friendly at 10:30 p.m. EDT July 24 at Levi\'s Stadium in Santa Clara, Calif.', 'source': {'uri': 'charlotteobserver.com', 'dataType': 'news', 'title': 'The Charlotte Observer'}, 'authors': [{'uri': 'alex_butler@charlotteobserver.com', 'name': 'Alex Butler', 'type': 'author', 'isAgency': False}], 'image': 'https://www.mcclatchy-wires.com/incoming/1tkrf2/picture290157759/alternates/LANDSCAPE_1140/158ff095-5df1-4500-830d-60a23216228c', 'eventUri': None, 'sentiment': -0.1686274509803921, 'wgt': 458929719, 'relevance': 100}

{'uri': '2024-07-425048724', 'lang': 'eng', 'isDuplicate': True, 'date': '2024-07-17', 'time': '16:27:41', 'dateTime': '2024-07-17T16:27:41Z', 'dateTimePub': '2024-07-17T15:56:02Z', 'dataType': 'news', 'sim': 0, 'url': 'https://www.myrtlebeachonline.com/sports/article290157804.html', 'title': 'FIFA investigates Argentina for racist Copa America celebration chant', 'body': 'July 17 (UPI) -- FIFA opened an investigation into Argentina after players were heard singing a racist chant while celebrating their victory over Colombia in the Copa America finale, the world soccer governing body said Wednesday.\n\n"FIFA is aware of a video circulating on social media and the incident is being looked into," FIFA said in a statement. "FIFA strongly condemns any form of discrimination by anyone including players, fans and officials."\n\nA video of the players signing the chant surfaced after the Argentines beat Colombia 1-0 on Sunday at Hard Rock Stadium in Miami Gardens, Fla.\n\nArgentina midfielder Enzo Fernandez was among the players who posted footage from a bus, featuring his teammates singing the chant that included racist and homophobic insults. The song also features a slight directed at France striker Kylian Mbappe, one of Argentine captain Lionel Messi\'s former teammates.\n\nThe chant, which some Argentina fans sang at the 2022 World Cup final during a win over France, also cites French players with African ancestors and others from immigrant families.\n\n"They play for France, but their parents are from Angola," part of the chant says. "Their mother is from Cameroon while their father is from Nigeria. But their passport says French."\n\nThe French Football Federation announced Tuesday that president Philippe Diallo made direct appeals to Argentina Football Association president Claudio Fabian Tapia and FIFA and filed a "legal complaint for racially offensive and discriminatory remarks."\n\nFernandez issued an apology Tuesday on Instagram, while admitting that the "song includes highly offensive language" and there was "absolutely no excuse" for the words.\n\n"I stand against discrimination in all forms and apologize for getting caught up in the euphoria of our Copa America celebrations," Fernandez wrote on his Instagram story.\n\n"That video, that moment, those words, do not reflect my beliefs or my character. I am truly sorry."\n\nFernandez\'s club team, Chelsea, also issued a statement, calling all forms of "discriminatory behavior completely unacceptable."\n\n"We acknowledge and appreciate our players\' public apology and will use this as an opportunity to educate," the Premier League club said. "The club has instigated an internal disciplinary procedure."\n\nDefender Wesley Fofana, one of Fernandez\'s Black Chelsea teammates, reposted the video Tuesday on X, while writing: "Football in 2024: uninhibited racism." Fofana was born in France. His mother is French, while his father is from West Africa.\n\nNeither the Argentina Football Association nor Messi have made public comments about the incident. Representatives for both parties did not immediately respond when asked for statements on the incident or investigation.\n\nConcacaf and CONMEBOL, the South American organizations that organize Copa America, also did not immediately respond when asked for comment.\n\nChelsea will host Wrexham in a friendly at 10:30 p.m. EDT July 24 at Levi\'s Stadium in Santa Clara, Calif.', 'source': {'uri': 'myrtlebeachonline.com', 'dataType': 'news', 'title': 'MyrtleBeachOnline'}, 'authors': [{'uri': 'alex_butler@myrtlebeachonline.com', 'name': 'Alex Butler', 'type': 'author', 'isAgency': False}], 'image': 'https://www.mcclatchy-wires.com/incoming/1tkrf2/picture290157759/alternates/LANDSCAPE_1140/158ff095-5df1-4500-830d-60a23216228c', 'eventUri': None, 'sentiment': -0.1686274509803921, 'wgt': 458929661, 'relevance': 100}

"FIFA strongly condemns any form of discrimination by anyone including players, fans and officials."\n\nA video of the players signing the chant surfaced after the Argentines beat Colombia 1-0 on Sunday at Hard Rock Stadium in Miami Gardens, Fla.\n\nArgentina midfielder Enzo Fernandez was among the players who posted footage from a bus, featuring his teammates singing the chant that included racist and homophobic insults. The song also features a slight directed at France striker Kylian Mbappe, one of Argentine captain Lionel Messi\'s former teammates.\n\nThe chant, which some Argentina fans sang at the 2022 World Cup final during a win over France, also cites French players with African ancestors and others from immigrant families.\n\n"They play for France, but their parents are from Angola," part of the chant says. "Their mother is from Cameroon while their father is from Nigeria. But their passport says French."\n\nThe French Football Federation announced Tuesday that president Philippe Diallo made direct appeals to Argentina Football Association president Claudio Fabian Tapia and FIFA and filed a "legal complaint for racially offensive and discriminatory remarks."\n\nFernandez issued an apology Tuesday on Instagram, while admitting that the "song includes highly offensive language" and there was "absolutely no excuse" for the words.\n\n"I stand against discrimination in all forms and apologize for getting caught up in the euphoria of our Copa America celebrations," Fernandez wrote on his Instagram story.\n\n"That video, that moment, those words, do not reflect my beliefs or my character. I am truly sorry."\n\nFernandez\'s club team, Chelsea, also issued a statement, calling all forms of "discriminatory behavior completely unacceptable."\n\n"We acknowledge and appreciate our players\' public apology and will use this as an opportunity to educate," the Premier League club said. "The club has instigated an internal disciplinary procedure."\n\nDefender Wesley Fofana, one of Fernandez\'s Black Chelsea teammates, reposted the video Tuesday on X, while writing: "Football in 2024: uninhibited racism." Fofana was born in France. His mother is French, while his father is from West Africa.\n\nNeither the Argentina Football Association nor Messi have made public comments about the incident. {'uri': '2024-07-425044841', 'lang': 'eng', 'isDuplicate': True, 'date': '2024-07-17', 'time': '16:22:58', 'dateTime': '2024-07-17T16:22:58Z', 'dateTimePub': '2024-07-17T15:56:02Z', 'dataType': 'news', 'sim': 0, 'url': 'https://www.sanluisobispo.com/sports/article290157804.html', 'title': 'FIFA investigates Argentina for racist Copa America celebration chant', 'body': 'July 17 (UPI) -- FIFA opened an investigation into Argentina after players were heard singing a racist chant while celebrating their victory over Colombia in the Copa America finale, the world soccer governing body said Wednesday.\n\n"FIFA is aware of a video circulating on social media and the incident is being looked into," FIFA said in a statement. "FIFA strongly condemns any form of discrimination by anyone including players, fans and officials."\n\nA video of the players signing the chant surfaced after the Argentines beat Colombia 1-0 on Sunday at Hard Rock Stadium in Miami Gardens, Fla.\n\nArgentina midfielder Enzo Fernandez was among the players who posted footage from a bus, featuring his teammates singing the chant that included racist and homophobic insults. The song also features a slight directed at France striker Kylian Mbappe, one of Argentine captain Lionel Messi\'s former teammates.\n\nThe chant, which some Argentina fans sang at the 2022 World Cup final during a win over France, also cites French players with African ancestors and others from immigrant families.\n\n"They play for France, but their parents are from Angola," part of the chant says. "Their mother is from Cameroon while their father is from Nigeria. But their passport says French."\n\nThe French Football Federation announced Tuesday that president Philippe Diallo made direct appeals to Argentina Football Association president Claudio Fabian Tapia and FIFA and filed a "legal complaint for racially offensive and discriminatory remarks."\n\nFernandez issued an apology Tuesday on Instagram, while admitting that the "song includes highly offensive language" and there was "absolutely no excuse" for the words.\n\n"I stand against discrimination in all forms and apologize for getting caught up in the euphoria of our Copa America celebrations," Fernandez wrote on his Instagram story.\n\n"That video, that moment, those words, do not reflect my beliefs or my character. I am truly sorry."\n\nFernandez\'s club team, Chelsea, also issued a statement, calling all forms of "discriminatory behavior completely unacceptable."\n\n"We acknowledge and appreciate our players\' public apology and will use this as an opportunity to educate," the Premier League club said. "The club has instigated an internal disciplinary procedure."\n\nDefender Wesley Fofana, one of Fernandez\'s Black Chelsea teammates, reposted the video Tuesday on X, while writing: "Football in 2024: uninhibited racism." Fofana was born in France. His mother is French, while his father is from West Africa.\n\nNeither the Argentina Football Association nor Messi have made public comments about the incident. Representatives for both parties did not immediately respond when asked for statements on the incident or investigation.\n\nConcacaf and CONMEBOL, the South American organizations that organize Copa America, also did not immediately respond when asked for comment.\n\nChelsea will host Wrexham in a friendly at 10:30 p.m. EDT July 24 at Levi\'s Stadium in Santa Clara, Calif.', 'source': {'uri': 'sanluisobispo.com', 'dataType': 'news', 'title': 'The Tribune'}, 'authors': [{'uri': 'alex_butler@sanluisobispo.com', 'name': 'Alex Butler', 'type': 'author', 'isAgency': False}], 'image': 'https://www.mcclatchy-wires.com/incoming/1tkrf2/picture290157759/alternates/LANDSCAPE_1140/158ff095-5df1-4500-830d-60a23216228c', 'eventUri': None, 'sentiment': -0.1686274509803921, 'wgt': 458929378, 'relevance': 100}

A tal punto que, por ejemplo, el suplemento Ovaci√≥n (diario El Pa√≠s) realiz√≥ una nota donde despedaza el torneo y hasta o lo tilda de "desastre".\n\n"Una por una: las 10 razones para considerar que la Copa Am√©rica de Estados Unidos 2024 fue un desastre", es el titular de la cr√≥nica, que sentencia que "m√°s all√° de los resultados deportivos, la organizaci√≥n del torneo revel√≥ graves errores y malas decisiones de la Conmebol, que significaron un gran paso atr√°s en la evoluci√≥n del f√∫tbol continental".\n\nEn cuanto a los motivos del peri√≥dico uruguayo, hay que destacar que se mencionan situaciones tanto futbol√≠sticas como extra futbol√≠sticas.\n\nS√≠, porque comienza cuestionando la inauguraci√≥n y el discurso de pastores evang√©licos, pero tambi√©n lamenta las dimensiones de los campos de juego.\n\nLa presentaci√≥n de la artista y estrella mundial en la final, Shakira, tambi√©n fue criticada. A continuaci√≥n, las diez razones:\n\n1) Fixture mal armado: Hicieron todo para que Argentina y Brasil solo se cruzaran en la final. Por eso se repiti√≥ Argentina-Canad√° en una semifinal. Y si Brasil le ganaba a Uruguay, se hubiera repetido la otra semi.\n\n2) Inauguraci√≥n muy aburrida: La ceremonia inaugural fue breve y aburrida, sin demasiado color. Tan olvidable que nadie la debe recordar ahora. Y eso que tuvieron mucho tiempo para prepararla...\n\n3) La presencia del pastor, fuera de lugar: El discurso inaugural de un pastor evang√©lico paraguayo viol√≥ uno de las normas de la FIFA, en el sentido de que no deben expresarse opiniones pol√≠ticas o religiosas en las competencias.\n\n4) El p√©simo estado de las canchas: Una queja casi un√°nime de t√©cnicos y jugadores. La colocaci√≥n de c√©sped natural a √∫ltimo momento sobre pisos sint√©ticos no result√≥. Tampoco los campos de entrenamiento estaban en condiciones.\n\n5) Las ins√≥litas dimensiones de las canchas: La utilizaci√≥n de estadios de f√∫tbol americano oblig√≥ a achicar las dimensiones de las canchas. En el estadio MetLife, hab√≠a tan poco espacio que no se ve√≠a por TV la l√≠nea de costado.\n\n6) Las temperaturas agobiantes: Hizo calor en todas las sedes, pero en las del centro del pa√≠s, donde los veranos son tremendos, las temperaturas fueron inapropiadas para hacer deporte. Hasta se desmay√≥ un √°rbitro asistente...\n\n7) Viajes de largas distancias: Muchas selecciones fueron obligadas a jugar en puntos distantes del enorme territorio estadounidenses de un partido para otro. Uruguay, por ejemplo, sum√≥ 8.311 km en vuelos.\n\n8) Familiares sin protecci√≥n: Sin controles sobre la venta de alcohol, sin protecci√≥n especial para familiares de jugadores en la tribuna, se vivieron momentos de gran tensi√≥n al final del partido Uruguay-Colombia.\n\n9) El entretiempo ilegal de la final: El espect√°culo de Shakira en el entretiempo de la final dur√≥ m√°s de 25 minutos, cuando las reglas del f√∫tbol establecen que los descansos no deben extenderse por m√°s de 15 minutos.\n\n10) El bochorno de la final: Para cerrar todos los desprop√≥sitos, la final empez√≥ 90 minutos m√°s tarde de lo previsto por los graves incidentes registrados luego que aficionados colombianos intentaran entrar sin boletos.', 'source': {'uri': 'biobiochile.cl', 'dataType': 'news', 'title': 'BioBioChile'}, 'authors': [], 'image': 'https://media.biobiochile.cl/wp-content/uploads/2024/07/social-copa-america-eeuu-diez-razones-un-desastre.jpg', 'eventUri': None, 'sentiment': None, 'wgt': 458929094, 'relevance': 100}

{'uri': '2024-07-425040160', 'lang': 'eng', 'isDuplicate': True, 'date': '2024-07-17', 'time': '16:17:57', 'dateTime': '2024-07-17T16:17:57Z', 'dateTimePub': '2024-07-17T15:56:02Z', 'dataType': 'news', 'sim': 0, 'url': 'https://www.sacbee.com/sports/article290157804.html', 'title': 'FIFA investigates Argentina for racist Copa America celebration chant', 'body': 'July 17 (UPI) -- FIFA opened an investigation into Argentina after players were heard singing a racist chant while celebrating their victory over Colombia in the Copa America finale, the world soccer governing body said Wednesday.\n\n"FIFA is aware of a video circulating on social media and the incident is being looked into," FIFA said in a statement. "FIFA strongly condemns any form of discrimination by anyone including players, fans and officials."\n\nA video of the players signing the chant surfaced after the Argentines beat Colombia 1-0 on Sunday at Hard Rock Stadium in Miami Gardens, Fla.\n\nArgentina midfielder Enzo Fernandez was among the players who posted footage from a bus, featuring his teammates singing the chant that included racist and homophobic insults. The song also features a slight directed at France striker Kylian Mbappe, one of Argentine captain Lionel Messi\'s former teammates.\n\nThe chant, which some Argentina fans sang at the 2022 World Cup final during a win over France, also cites French players with African ancestors and others from immigrant families.\n\n"They play for France, but their parents are from Angola," part of the chant says. "Their mother is from Cameroon while their father is from Nigeria. But their passport says French."\n\nThe French Football Federation announced Tuesday that president Philippe Diallo made direct appeals to Argentina Football Association president Claudio Fabian Tapia and FIFA and filed a "legal complaint for racially offensive and discriminatory remarks."\n\nFernandez issued an apology Tuesday on Instagram, while admitting that the "song includes highly offensive language" and there was "absolutely no excuse" for the words.\n\n"I stand against discrimination in all forms and apologize for getting caught up in the euphoria of our Copa America celebrations," Fernandez wrote on his Instagram story.\n\n"That video, that moment, those words, do not reflect my beliefs or my character. I am truly sorry."\n\nFernandez\'s club team, Chelsea, also issued a statement, calling all forms of "discriminatory behavior completely unacceptable."\n\n"We acknowledge and appreciate our players\' public apology and will use this as an opportunity to educate," the Premier League club said. "The club has instigated an internal disciplinary procedure."\n\nDefender Wesley Fofana, one of Fernandez\'s Black Chelsea teammates, reposted the video Tuesday on X, while writing: "Football in 2024: uninhibited racism." Ÿàÿ≠ŸÇŸàŸÇ ÿßŸÑÿ•ŸÜÿ≥ÿßŸÜÿå ŸÇÿ±ÿ± ÿ±ÿ¶Ÿäÿ≥ ÿßŸÑÿßÿ™ÿ≠ÿßÿØ ÿßŸÑŸÅÿ±ŸÜÿ≥Ÿä ÿßŸÑÿØÿÆŸàŸÑ ŸÅŸä ÿ™ÿ≠ÿØ ŸÖÿ®ÿßÿ¥ÿ± ŸÖÿπ ÿ±ÿ¶Ÿäÿ≥ ÿßŸÑÿßÿ™ÿ≠ÿßÿØ ÿßŸÑÿ£ÿ±ÿ¨ŸÜÿ™ŸäŸÜŸä Ÿàÿ±ÿ¶Ÿäÿ≥ ŸÅŸäŸÅÿßÿå ŸàÿßŸÑÿ™ŸÇÿØŸÖ ÿ®ÿ¥ŸÉŸàŸâ ŸÇÿßŸÜŸàŸÜŸäÿ© ÿ∂ÿØ Ÿáÿ∞Ÿá ÿßŸÑÿ™ÿµÿ±Ÿäÿ≠ÿßÿ™ ÿßŸÑŸÖÿ≥Ÿäÿ¶ÿ© ÿßŸÑÿ™Ÿä ÿ™ÿ≠ŸÖŸÑ ÿ∑ÿ®Ÿäÿπÿ© ÿπŸÜÿµÿ±Ÿäÿ© Ÿàÿ™ŸÖŸäŸäÿ≤Ÿäÿ©".\n\nŸàÿ™ÿ∫ŸÑÿ® ÿßŸÑŸÖŸÜÿ™ÿÆÿ® ÿßŸÑÿ£ÿ±ÿ¨ŸÜÿ™ŸäŸÜŸä ÿπŸÑŸâ ŸÜÿ∏Ÿäÿ±Ÿá Ÿäÿ™ÿπŸäŸÜ ÿØŸÅÿπ ÿ≠ŸàÿßŸÑŸä 28,578,240 ŸÖŸÑŸäŸàŸÜ ŸäŸàÿ±Ÿà ŸÑŸÑŸÅŸàÿ≤ ÿ®ÿÆÿØŸÖÿßÿ™ ÿßŸÑŸÑÿßÿπÿ®.\n\nÿØŸäŸÅŸäÿØ ŸÜŸäÿ±Ÿäÿ≥\n\nŸäŸÑÿπÿ® ÿßŸÑÿ¨ŸÜÿßÿ≠ ÿßŸÑÿ®ÿ±ÿßÿ≤ŸäŸÑŸä ÿØŸäŸÅŸäÿØ ŸÜŸäÿ±Ÿäÿ≥ ŸÑÿµÿßŸÑÿ≠ ŸÜÿßÿØŸä ÿ®ŸÜŸÅŸäŸÉÿß ÿßŸÑÿ®ÿ±ÿ™ÿ∫ÿßŸÑŸä. ŸÖÿ±ŸÉÿ≤ ÿßÿ®ŸÜ ÿßŸÑŸÄ27 ÿπÿßŸÖŸãÿß ŸÅŸä ÿßŸÑÿ¨ŸÜÿßÿ≠ ÿßŸÑÿ£ŸäŸÖŸÜ ŸÑŸÉŸÜŸá ŸäŸÖŸÉŸÜ ÿßÿ≥ÿ™ÿÆÿØÿßŸÖŸá ŸÉÿ¨ŸÜÿßÿ≠ ÿ£Ÿäÿ≥ÿ± ÿ®ÿßÿπÿ™ÿ®ÿßÿ±Ÿá Ÿäÿ≥ÿ™ÿπŸÖŸÑ ÿßŸÑŸÇÿØŸÖ ÿßŸÑŸäÿ≥ÿ±Ÿâ. {'uri': '2024-07-425036163', 'lang': 'eng', 'isDuplicate': True, 'date': '2024-07-17', 'time': '16:13:46', 'dateTime': '2024-07-17T16:13:46Z', 'dateTimePub': '2024-07-17T15:56:02Z', 'dataType': 'news', 'sim': 0, 'url': 'https://www.kentucky.com/sports/article290157804.html', 'title': 'FIFA investigates Argentina for racist Copa America celebration chant', 'body': 'July 17 (UPI) -- FIFA opened an investigation into Argentina after players were heard singing a racist chant while celebrating their victory over Colombia in the Copa America finale, the world soccer governing body said Wednesday.\n\n"FIFA is aware of a video circulating on social media and the incident is being looked into," FIFA said in a statement. "FIFA strongly condemns any form of discrimination by anyone including players, fans and officials."\n\nA video of the players signing the chant surfaced after the Argentines beat Colombia 1-0 on Sunday at Hard Rock Stadium in Miami Gardens, Fla.\n\nArgentina midfielder Enzo Fernandez was among the players who posted footage from a bus, featuring his teammates singing the chant that included racist and homophobic insults. The song also features a slight directed at France striker Kylian Mbappe, one of Argentine captain Lionel Messi\'s former teammates.\n\nThe chant, which some Argentina fans sang at the 2022 World Cup final during a win over France, also cites French players with African ancestors and others from immigrant families.\n\n"They play for France, but their parents are from Angola," part of the chant says. "Their mother is from Cameroon while their father is from Nigeria. But their passport says French."\n\nThe French Football Federation announced Tuesday that president Philippe Diallo made direct appeals to Argentina Football Association president Claudio Fabian Tapia and FIFA and filed a "legal complaint for racially offensive and discriminatory remarks."\n\nFernandez issued an apology Tuesday on Instagram, while admitting that the "song includes highly offensive language" and there was "absolutely no excuse" for the words.\n\n"I stand against discrimination in all forms and apologize for getting caught up in the euphoria of our Copa America celebrations," Fernandez wrote on his Instagram story.\n\n"That video, that moment, those words, do not reflect my beliefs or my character. I am truly sorry."\n\nFernandez\'s club team, Chelsea, also issued a statement, calling all forms of "discriminatory behavior completely unacceptable."\n\n"We acknowledge and appreciate our players\' public apology and will use this as an opportunity to educate," the Premier League club said. "The club has instigated an internal disciplinary procedure."\n\nDefender Wesley Fofana, one of Fernandez\'s Black Chelsea teammates, reposted the video Tuesday on X, while writing: "Football in 2024: uninhibited racism." Fofana was born in France. His mother is French, while his father is from West Africa.\n\nNeither the Argentina Football Association nor Messi have made public comments about the incident. Representatives for both parties did not immediately respond when asked for statements on the incident or investigation.\n\nConcacaf and CONMEBOL, the South American organizations that organize Copa America, also did not immediately respond when asked for comment.\n\nChelsea will host Wrexham in a friendly at 10:30 p.m. EDT July 24 at Levi\'s Stadium in Santa Clara, Calif.', 'source': {'uri': 'kentucky.com', 'dataType': 'news', 'title': 'Lexington Herald Leader'}, 'authors': [{'uri': 'alex_butler@kentucky.com', 'name': 'Alex Butler', 'type': 'author', 'isAgency': False}], 'image': 'https://www.mcclatchy-wires.com/incoming/1tkrf2/picture290157759/alternates/LANDSCAPE_1140/158ff095-5df1-4500-830d-60a23216228c', 'eventUri': None, 'sentiment': -0.1686274509803921, 'wgt': 458928826, 'relevance': 100}

"FIFA strongly condemns any form of discrimination by anyone including players, fans and officials."\n\nChelsea defender Wesley Fofana described the video posted to social media by his club team mate Enzo Fernandez as "uninhibited racism".\n\nFernandez later apologised on social media, saying he had gotten "caught up in the euphoria of our celebrations."\n\n"The song included highly offensive language and there is absolutely no excuse for these words," he wrote.\n\nThe Premier League side said in a statement on Wednesday: "Chelsea Football Club finds all forms of discriminatory behaviour completely unacceptable. {'uri': '8230326379', 'lang': 'eng', 'isDuplicate': False, 'date': '2024-07-17', 'time': '16:11:13', 'dateTime': '2024-07-17T16:11:13Z', 'dateTimePub': '2024-07-17T16:10:39Z', 'dataType': 'news', 'sim': 0.5960784554481506, 'url': 'https://www.nytimes.com/athletic/5633308/2024/07/17/liverpool-slot-preseason-salah-euro2024-copa/', 'title': "Arne Slot faces a challenging pre-season as Liverpool await the cavalry's return", 'body': '"It\'s important to show your mentality. Show the lads how it\'s done as leaders in the group," bellowed Liverpool\'s first-team fitness coach Conall Murtagh as Mohamed Salah and Wataru Endo set off on the punishing six-minute race test at Kirkby.\n\nSalah certainly rose to the challenge as he covered more ground than any of his team-mates -- knocking Sepp van den Berg off the top of the leaderboard.\n\n"Phenomenal," was Murtagh\'s verdict.\n\nThe Egyptian turned 32 last month but is showing no signs of slowing down. He returned for pre-season last week in incredible shape and has been setting the standards for others to follow both in the gym and on the training field. He is the perfect role model for the array of youngsters trying to force their way into Arne Slot\'s plans.\n\nWhat an asset for the new head coach, especially at a time when the squad the Dutchman inherited from Jurgen Klopp is shorn of so much star talent.\n\nThe trio of Andy Robertson, Dominik Szoboszlai and young goalkeeper Vitezslav Jaros reported back to Kirkby on Tuesday after enjoying a break following their involvement at Euro 2024. Their participation at the summer tournament ended at the group stage.\n\nHowever, nearly a fortnight into pre-season, Slot is still without 11 senior players and unable to work with most of his strongest line-up.\n\nThe scenario is far from ideal as he and his staff try to get their ideas across. Only Chelsea among last season\'s Premier League top eight find themselves in a similar position with a new manager having taken up the reins.\n\nSlot will only have around 10 days to work with the full squad before the Premier League opener at newly promoted Ipswich Town on August 17. Deciding when and how to reintegrate those who missed such a large chunk of pre-season will be key. There has to be a balance struck between looking at the bigger picture and trying to ensure the honeymoon period isn\'t cut short prematurely.\n\nThere will certainly be plenty of big names missing when Liverpool fly to Pittsburgh for the start of their pre-season tour of the United States next Tuesday. Their opening friendly is against Real Betis three days later.\n\nTrent Alexander-Arnold and Joe Gomez went on holiday following England\'s defeat to Spain in the final of the Euros last Sunday. Alexis Mac Allister helped Argentina triumph over Luis Diaz\'s Colombia in the final of the Copa America on the same day. Darwin Nunez was part of the Uruguay side who had beaten Canada in the third-place play-off 24 hours earlier.\n\nThe standard three-week break given to players post-tournament would mean that the quintet will not be starting their fitness testing until after Liverpool arrive home from the U.S. on August 4.\n\nThe Dutch trio of Virgil van Dijk, Cody Gakpo and Ryan Gravenberch, as well as France\'s Ibrahima Konate -- who all suffered semi-final heartache in the Euros -- are due to return a few days earlier, but it is unlikely Liverpool would fly them out for the last leg of the tour in Columbia, North Carolina.\n\nThere\'s a decision to be made on Portugal\'s Diogo Jota and Brazil\'s Alisson who, having reached the last eight in their respective tournaments, would be scheduled to report back around July 28 when Liverpool will be based in Philadelphia. Would they be better served doing fitness work back at Kirkby rather than embarking on a 7,000-mile round trip?\n\nGomez, Gravenberch and Konate did not play a single minute at the Euros, so they may decide to return early, but it is down to the individuals themselves with no pressure exerted by the club.\n\nSome are in desperate need of a rest after such a gruelling campaign.\n\nIncluding the warm-up games before the tournaments, Diaz had the biggest international workload as he clocked up 660 minutes for Colombia following the end of the domestic season with Liverpool. Van Dijk was next on 648 minutes with the Netherlands followed by Gakpo (600 minutes), Nunez (544), Alisson (540), Mac Allister (507), Alexander-Arnold (250), Jota (232), Konate (118), Gravenberch (86) and Gomez (43).\n\nSome benefitted massively from the experience -- there was another major trophy for Mac Allister to celebrate and a share of the Golden Boot at the Euros for the impressive Gakpo.\n\nFor Alexander-Arnold and Jota, there was frustration at spending so much time watching from the bench. For Nunez, there\'s an anxious wait to discover the outcome of CONMEBOL\'s disciplinary investigation into the scenes that marred the aftermath of Uruguay\'s defeat to Colombia, when he climbed into the stand to confront rival supporters due to concerns about his family\'s safety. Nunez scored in Uruguay\'s opening two games but then fired blanks in the next four.\n\nSlot\'s backroom staff has come together, with former Netherlands and Everton defender John Heitinga the latest addition as assistant coach.\n\nThe 40-year-old\'s arrival follows the appointments of Sipke Hulshoff (assistant), Ruben Peeters (lead physical performance coach), Aaron Briggs (first-team individual development coach) and Fabian Otte (head of first-team goalkeeping coaching). Heitinga\'s Premier League experience from his spell as part of David Moyes\' staff at West Ham United appealed to Slot.\n\nHowever, the wait for business to be done in the transfer market goes on as Slot puts a youthful, depleted squad through its paces.\n\nAside from Salah, it will be a shadow Liverpool front line which takes to the field in the U.S. next week. It will be a similar story defensively, but they are reasonably well-stocked in midfield.\n\nSlot is hands-on when it comes to training and the feedback on his innovative sessions at Kirkby has been very positive, but his first pre-season has been complicated by so many players going so far in the Euros and the Copa America. {'uri': '2024-07-425032296', 'lang': 'eng', 'isDuplicate': True, 'date': '2024-07-17', 'time': '16:10:57', 'dateTime': '2024-07-17T16:10:57Z', 'dateTimePub': '2024-07-17T15:56:02Z', 'dataType': 'news', 'sim': 0, 'url': 'https://www.bradenton.com/sports/article290157804.html', 'title': 'FIFA investigates Argentina for racist Copa America celebration chant', 'body': 'July 17 (UPI) -- FIFA opened an investigation into Argentina after players were heard singing a racist chant while celebrating their victory over Colombia in the Copa America finale, the world soccer governing body said Wednesday.\n\n"FIFA is aware of a video circulating on social media and the incident is being looked into," FIFA said in a statement. "FIFA strongly condemns any form of discrimination by anyone including players, fans and officials."\n\nA video of the players signing the chant surfaced after the Argentines beat Colombia 1-0 on Sunday at Hard Rock Stadium in Miami Gardens, Fla.\n\nArgentina midfielder Enzo Fernandez was among the players who posted footage from a bus, featuring his teammates singing the chant that included racist and homophobic insults. The song also features a slight directed at France striker Kylian Mbappe, one of Argentine captain Lionel Messi\'s former teammates.\n\nThe chant, which some Argentina fans sang at the 2022 World Cup final during a win over France, also cites French players with African ancestors and others from immigrant families.\n\n"They play for France, but their parents are from Angola," part of the chant says. "Their mother is from Cameroon while their father is from Nigeria. But their passport says French."\n\nThe French Football Federation announced Tuesday that president Philippe Diallo made direct appeals to Argentina Football Association president Claudio Fabian Tapia and FIFA and filed a "legal complaint for racially offensive and discriminatory remarks."\n\nFernandez issued an apology Tuesday on Instagram, while admitting that the "song includes highly offensive language" and there was "absolutely no excuse" for the words.\n\n"I stand against discrimination in all forms and apologize for getting caught up in the euphoria of our Copa America celebrations," Fernandez wrote on his Instagram story.\n\n"That video, that moment, those words, do not reflect my beliefs or my character. I am truly sorry."\n\nFernandez\'s club team, Chelsea, also issued a statement, calling all forms of "discriminatory behavior completely unacceptable."\n\n"We acknowledge and appreciate our players\' public apology and will use this as an opportunity to educate," the Premier League club said. "The club has instigated an internal disciplinary procedure."\n\nDefender Wesley Fofana, one of Fernandez\'s Black Chelsea teammates, reposted the video Tuesday on X, while writing: "Football in 2024: uninhibited racism." Fofana was born in France. His mother is French, while his father is from West Africa.\n\nNeither the Argentina Football Association nor Messi have made public comments about the incident. Representatives for both parties did not immediately respond when asked for statements on the incident or investigation.\n\nConcacaf and CONMEBOL, the South American organizations that organize Copa America, also did not immediately respond when asked for comment.\n\nChelsea will host Wrexham in a friendly at 10:30 p.m. EDT July 24 at Levi\'s Stadium in Santa Clara, Calif.', 'source': {'uri': 'bradenton.com', 'dataType': 'news', 'title': 'Bradenton Herald'}, 'authors': [{'uri': 'alex_butler@bradenton.com', 'name': 'Alex Butler', 'type': 'author', 'isAgency': False}], 'image': 'https://www.mcclatchy-wires.com/incoming/1tkrf2/picture290157759/alternates/LANDSCAPE_1140/158ff095-5df1-4500-830d-60a23216228c', 'eventUri': None, 'sentiment': -0.1686274509803921, 'wgt': 458928657, 'relevance': 100}

ÿπŸÇÿ® ŸÅŸàÿ≤ŸáŸÖ ÿπŸÑŸâ ŸÉŸàŸÑŸàŸÖÿ®Ÿäÿß ŸÅŸä ÿßŸÑŸÖÿ®ÿßÿ±ÿßÿ© ÿßŸÑŸÜŸáÿßÿ¶Ÿäÿ© ÿ®ÿ®ÿ∑ŸàŸÑÿ© ŸÉŸàÿ®ÿß ÿ£ŸÖŸäÿ±ŸÉÿß.\n\nŸàÿ™ÿ£ÿ™Ÿä ÿßŸÑÿ¥ŸÉŸàŸâ ÿπŸÇÿ® ÿ∏ŸáŸàÿ± ŸÖŸÇÿ∑ÿπ ŸÅŸäÿØŸäŸà ŸÜÿ¥ÿ±Ÿá ŸÑÿßÿπÿ® Ÿàÿ≥ÿ∑ ÿ™ÿ¥ŸÑÿ≥Ÿä ŸÅÿ±ŸÜÿßŸÜÿØŸäÿ≤ÿå ÿ≠Ÿäÿ´ Ÿäÿ∏Ÿáÿ± ŸáŸà Ÿàÿ≤ŸÖŸÑÿßÿ§Ÿá ŸàŸáŸÖ ŸäŸáÿ™ŸÅŸàŸÜ ÿ∂ÿØ ÿßŸÑŸÖŸÜÿ™ÿÆÿ® ÿßŸÑŸÅÿ±ŸÜÿ≥Ÿä ÿ£ÿ´ŸÜÿßÿ° ÿßÿ≠ÿ™ŸÅÿßŸÑŸáŸÖ ÿ®ÿßŸÑŸÅŸàÿ≤ 1-ÿµŸÅÿ± ÿπŸÑŸâ ŸÉŸàŸÑŸàŸÖÿ®Ÿäÿß ŸÅŸä ÿßŸÑŸÖÿ®ÿßÿ±ÿßÿ© ÿßŸÑŸÜŸáÿßÿ¶Ÿäÿ© ŸÑŸÉŸàÿ®ÿß ÿ£ŸÖŸäÿ±ŸÉÿß ÿßŸÑÿ™Ÿä ÿ£ŸÇŸäŸÖÿ™ ÿßŸÑÿ£ÿ≠ÿØ ÿßŸÑŸÖÿßÿ∂Ÿä.\n\nŸàŸÜÿ¥ÿ± ŸÅÿ±ŸÜÿßŸÜÿØŸäÿ≤ ÿ®ŸäÿßŸÜÿß ÿπŸÑŸâ ÿ≠ÿ≥ÿßÿ®Ÿá ÿ£ÿ¥ŸÉÿßŸÑŸá Ÿàÿ£ÿπÿ™ÿ∞ÿ± ŸÑÿßŸÜÿ¨ÿ±ÿßŸÅŸä ŸÅŸä ŸÜÿ¥Ÿàÿ© ÿßŸÑÿßÿ≠ÿ™ŸÅÿßŸÑÿßÿ™ ÿ®ŸÑŸÇÿ® ŸÉŸàÿ®ÿß ÿ£ŸÖŸäÿ±ŸÉÿß".\n\nŸàÿ£ÿ±ÿØŸÅ "ŸÑÿß ŸäÿπŸÉÿ≥ Ÿáÿ∞ÿß ÿßŸÑŸÅŸäÿØŸäŸàÿå ŸàŸÑÿß Ÿáÿ∞Ÿá ÿßŸÑŸÑÿ≠ÿ∏ÿ©ÿå ŸàŸÑÿß ŸÅÿßÿ®ŸäÿßŸÜ ÿ™ÿßÿ®Ÿäÿßÿå ÿ±ÿ¶Ÿäÿ≥ ÿßŸÑÿßÿ™ÿ≠ÿßÿØ ÿßŸÑÿ£ÿ±ÿ¨ŸÜÿ™ŸäŸÜŸä ŸÑŸÉÿ±ÿ© ÿßŸÑŸÇÿØŸÖÿå ÿ®ÿßŸÑÿ±ÿØ ÿπŸÑŸâ Ÿáÿ∞Ÿá ÿßŸÑŸÖÿ≤ÿßÿπŸÖ.\n\nŸàÿ¨ÿßÿ° ŸÅŸä ÿßŸÑÿ®ŸäÿßŸÜ "ŸäÿØŸäŸÜ ÿ±ÿ¶Ÿäÿ≥ ÿßŸÑÿßÿ™ÿ≠ÿßÿØ ÿßŸÑŸÅÿ±ŸÜÿ≥Ÿä ŸÑŸÉÿ±ÿ© ÿßŸÑŸÇÿØŸÖÿå ŸÅŸäŸÑŸäÿ®Ÿä ÿØŸäÿßŸÑŸàÿå ÿ®ÿ£ÿ¥ÿØ ÿßŸÑÿπÿ®ÿßÿ±ÿßÿ™ ÿßŸÑÿ™ÿµÿ±Ÿäÿ≠ÿßÿ™ ÿßŸÑÿπŸÜÿµÿ±Ÿäÿ© ŸàÿßŸÑÿ™ŸÖŸäŸäÿ≤Ÿäÿ© ÿ∫Ÿäÿ± ÿßŸÑŸÖŸÇÿ®ŸàŸÑÿ© ÿßŸÑŸÖŸàÿ¨Ÿáÿ© ÿ∂ÿØ ŸÑÿßÿπÿ®Ÿä ÿßŸÑŸÖŸÜÿ™ÿÆÿ® ÿßŸÑŸÅÿ±ŸÜÿ≥Ÿä ŸÅŸä ÿ≥ŸäÿßŸÇ ÿ£ÿ∫ŸÜŸäÿ©ÿå ÿ±ÿØÿØŸáÿß ŸÑÿßÿπÿ®Ÿà ŸàŸÖÿ¥ÿ¨ÿπŸà ÿßŸÑŸÖŸÜÿ™ÿÆÿ® ÿßŸÑÿ£ÿ±ÿ¨ŸÜÿ™ŸäŸÜŸä ÿπŸÇÿ® ÿßŸÑŸÅŸàÿ≤ ÿ®ŸÉŸàÿ®ÿß ÿ£ŸÖŸäÿ±ŸÉÿß Ÿàÿ™ŸÖ ŸÜÿ¥ÿ±Ÿáÿß ÿπÿ®ÿ± ŸÅŸäÿØŸäŸà ÿπŸÑŸâ Ÿàÿ≥ÿßÿ¶ŸÑ ÿßŸÑÿ™ŸàÿßÿµŸÑ ÿßŸÑÿßÿ¨ÿ™ŸÖÿßÿπŸä".\n\nŸàÿ£ÿ∂ÿßŸÅ "ŸÅŸä ŸÖŸàÿßÿ¨Ÿáÿ© ÿ¨ÿØŸäÿ© ŸÑŸáÿ∞Ÿá ÿßŸÑÿ™ÿµÿ±Ÿäÿ≠ÿßÿ™ ÿßŸÑÿµÿßÿØŸÖÿ©ÿå ÿßŸÑÿ™Ÿä ÿ™ÿÆÿßŸÑŸÅ ÿßŸÑŸÇŸäŸÖ ÿßŸÑÿ±Ÿäÿßÿ∂Ÿäÿ© Ÿàÿ≠ŸÇŸàŸÇ ÿßŸÑÿ•ŸÜÿ≥ÿßŸÜÿå ŸÇÿ±ÿ± ÿ±ÿ¶Ÿäÿ≥ ÿßŸÑÿßÿ™ÿ≠ÿßÿØ ÿßŸÑŸÅÿ±ŸÜÿ≥Ÿä ÿßŸÑÿØÿÆŸàŸÑ ŸÅŸä ÿ™ÿ≠ÿØ ŸÖÿ®ÿßÿ¥ÿ± ŸÖÿπ ÿ±ÿ¶Ÿäÿ≥ ÿßŸÑÿßÿ™ÿ≠ÿßÿØ ÿßŸÑÿ£ÿ±ÿ¨ŸÜÿ™ŸäŸÜŸä Ÿàÿ±ÿ¶Ÿäÿ≥ ŸÅŸäŸÅÿßÿå ŸàÿßŸÑÿ™ŸÇÿØŸÖ ÿ®ÿ¥ŸÉŸàŸâ ŸÇÿßŸÜŸàŸÜŸäÿ© ÿ∂ÿØ Ÿáÿ∞Ÿá ÿßŸÑÿ™ÿµÿ±Ÿäÿ≠ÿßÿ™ ÿßŸÑŸÖÿ≥Ÿäÿ¶ÿ© ÿßŸÑÿ™Ÿä ÿ™ÿ≠ŸÖŸÑ ÿ∑ÿ®Ÿäÿπÿ© ÿπŸÜÿµÿ±Ÿäÿ© Ÿàÿ™ŸÖŸäŸäÿ≤Ÿäÿ©".\n\nŸàÿ™ÿ∫ŸÑÿ® ÿßŸÑŸÖŸÜÿ™ÿÆÿ® ÿßŸÑÿ£ÿ±ÿ¨ŸÜÿ™ŸäŸÜŸä ÿπŸÑŸâ ŸÜÿ∏Ÿäÿ±Ÿá ÿßŸÑŸÅÿ±ŸÜÿ≥Ÿä ÿ®ÿ±ŸÉŸÑÿßÿ™ ÿßŸÑÿ™ÿ±ÿ¨Ÿäÿ≠ ŸÅŸä ŸÜŸáÿßÿ¶Ÿä ŸÉÿ£ÿ≥ ÿßŸÑÿπÿßŸÑŸÖ 2022 ÿ®ŸÇÿ∑ÿ±ÿå ŸàŸáŸä ÿßŸÑŸÖÿ®ÿßÿ±ÿßÿ© ÿßŸÑÿ™Ÿä ÿ≥ŸÖÿπ ŸÅŸäŸáÿß ŸÇŸäÿßŸÖ ÿßŸÑÿ¨ŸÖÿßŸáŸäÿ± ÿßŸÑÿ£ÿ±ÿ¨ŸÜÿ™ŸäŸÜŸäÿ© ÿ®ÿ£ÿØÿßÿ° ÿ®ÿπÿ∂ ÿßŸÑÿ£ÿ∫ÿßŸÜŸä ÿßŸÑÿ™ŸÖŸäŸäÿ≤Ÿäÿ©.', 'source': {'uri': 'ajnet.me', 'dataType': 'news', 'title': 'ÿßŸÑÿ¨ÿ≤Ÿäÿ±ÿ© ŸÜÿ™'}, 'authors': [], 'image': 'https://www.ajnet.me/wp-content/uploads/2024/07/doc-364969h-1721228941.jpg?resize=1920%2C1440', 'eventUri': 'ara-1675678', 'sentiment': None, 'wgt': 458928586, 'relevance': 100}
{'uri': '2024-07-425031615', 'lang': 'eng', 'isDuplicate': True, 'date': '2024-07-17', 'time': '16:09:44', 'dateTime': '2024-07-17T16:09:44Z', 'dateTimePub': '2024-07-17T15:56:02Z', 'dataType': 'news', 'sim': 0, 'url': 'https://www.thenewstribune.com/sports/article290157804.html', 'title': 'FIFA investigates Argentina for racist Copa America celebration chant', 'body': 'July 17 (UPI) -- FIFA opened an investigation into Argentina after players were heard singing a racist chant while celebrating their victory over Colombia in the Copa America finale, the world soccer governing body said Wednesday.\n\n"FIFA is aware of a video circulating on social media and the incident is being looked into," FIFA said in a statement. "FIFA strongly condemns any form of discrimination by anyone including players, fans and officials."\n\nA video of the players signing the chant surfaced after the Argentines beat Colombia 1-0 on Sunday at Hard Rock Stadium in Miami Gardens, Fla.\n\nArgentina midfielder Enzo Fernandez was among the players who posted footage from a bus, featuring his teammates singing the chant that included racist and homophobic insults. The song also features a slight directed at France striker Kylian Mbappe, one of Argentine captain Lionel Messi\'s former teammates.\n\nThe chant, which some Argentina fans sang at the 2022 World Cup final during a win over France, also cites French players with African ancestors and others from immigrant families.\n\n"They play for France, but their parents are from Angola," part of the chant says. "Their mother is from Cameroon while their father is from Nigeria. But their passport says French."\n\nThe French Football Federation announced Tuesday that president Philippe Diallo made direct appeals to Argentina Football Association president Claudio Fabian Tapia and FIFA and filed a "legal complaint for racially offensive and discriminatory remarks."\n\nFernandez issued an apology Tuesday on Instagram, while admitting that the "song includes highly offensive language" and there was "absolutely no excuse" for the words.\n\n"I stand against discrimination in all forms and apologize for getting caught up in the euphoria of our Copa America celebrations," Fernandez wrote on his Instagram story.\n\n"That video, that moment, those words, do not reflect my beliefs or my character. I am truly sorry."\n\nFernandez\'s club team, Chelsea, also issued a statement, calling all forms of "discriminatory behavior completely unacceptable."\n\n"We acknowledge and appreciate our players\' public apology and will use this as an opportunity to educate," the Premier League club said. "The club has instigated an internal disciplinary procedure."\n\nDefender Wesley Fofana, one of Fernandez\'s Black Chelsea teammates, reposted the video Tuesday on X, while writing: "Football in 2024: uninhibited racism." Fofana was born in France. His mother is French, while his father is from West Africa.\n\nNeither the Argentina Football Association nor Messi have made public comments about the incident. Representatives for both parties did not immediately respond when asked for statements on the incident or investigation.\n\nConcacaf and CONMEBOL, the South American organizations that organize Copa America, also did not immediately respond when asked for comment.\n\nChelsea will host Wrexham in a friendly at 10:30 p.m. EDT July 24 at Levi\'s Stadium in Santa Clara, Calif.', 'source': {'uri': 'thenewstribune.com', 'dataType': 'news', 'title': 'The News Tribune'}, 'authors': [{'uri': 'alex_butler@thenewstribune.com', 'name': 'Alex Butler', 'type': 'author', 'isAgency': False}], 'image': 'https://www.mcclatchy-wires.com/incoming/1tkrf2/picture290157759/alternates/LANDSCAPE_1140/158ff095-5df1-4500-830d-60a23216228c', 'eventUri': None, 'sentiment': -0.1686274509803921, 'wgt': 458928584, 'relevance': 100}

"FIFA strongly condemns any form of discrimination by anyone including players, fans and officials."\n\nA video of the players signing the chant surfaced after the Argentines beat Colombia 1-0 on Sunday at Hard Rock Stadium in Miami Gardens, Fla.\n\nArgentina midfielder Enzo Fernandez was among the players who posted footage from a bus, featuring his teammates singing the chant that included racist and homophobic insults. The song also features a slight directed at France striker Kylian Mbappe, one of Argentine captain Lionel Messi\'s former teammates.\n\nThe chant, which some Argentina fans sang at the 2022 World Cup final during a win over France, also cites French players with African ancestors and others from immigrant families.\n\n"They play for France, but their parents are from Angola," part of the chant says.
